is this business problem unique to you know my

all the commercial vendors of software in all domains have this kind of integration problem and it's a very

for building applications and there's no shortage of people coming year after year with new mouse traps for building

i actually think is is a problem where there's more interesting business value to be had

so how have we how have we done application integration in the past and again i've expressed this in in
using the example of tools from our domain but i think you know you could substitute another domain without
difficulty well there's two main models i contend or i assert you
can contest it if you like but i think there's two main models that people have worked with for probably as long as i've been
working one of them one of them is the standard sort of api model and we've sort of formalized it in
different kind of ways your service oriented architecture is the is the sort of uh there's a marketing term that recently
has had some success in describing this model and it's pretty straightforward you have all these you have all of these kind of applications
and each one of these applications opens up an api so my little kind of socket diagrams are designed are
attempting uh to symbolize those apis that get opened up by these applications and then
you write a bunch of glue code for tying them together and sometimes the glue code is in one application using the api of another application and sometimes the
glue code is in some third place we're sitting on some enterprise service bus or something
doing these kind of things but it's basically sort of apis and glue code um and
the actual data that's stored in the applications is kind of relevant you know it's important but it's a secondary kind of thing you know the first thing
is my application is the center of the universe with its api being its public face and the data that i hold you know
that's my data right so we don't it's there but it's not primary um
and actually the way that you address these things is typically very variable each api makes up its own way of how you
actually address the data that's behind it um this is a chart i found i found this
chart this is an ibm chart from around 1990. so
22 years ago everybody already knew that that model
that you know this model's actually been successful and it's still the dominant model and it's actually delivered a lot of value everybody's done it you know
both in the industry that i work in but in many others as well and it sort of adds value and it gets you so far but
it's pretty unsatisfactory in different kinds of ways you know where we never have enough glue code we never have enough apis every time you update the
versions the apis change and the glue code breaks we have
there are many sort of issues with it and so the other big idea that people have had forever is if we could just get
all of this data in one database sometimes it's sometimes people prefer to call it a repository
rather than a database if we could just get it all in the database all of this difficulty would go away everybody would
we'd all put the data in the database then you could query over the database uh all kinds of good things would happen
um and ibm had a project called ediecycle in 1990 that tried to do this and many others in fact there's still
many vendors whose that's their basic strategy we could just call get it in our database or our repository
everything would be good um and it doesn't really work right because it doesn't support it doesn't support heterogeneous environments what
do you do if you go into a customer organization and they've got you know stuff from all over the place what do
you do with legacy stuff um it doesn't it's a big sort of um
it's a big sort of soviet planned economy kind of view of the thing it sort of assumes that i can manage this repository and i can manage its schema
and all of these kind of things so there's many reasons why this model has failed for decades and
will continue to fail as long as people try to do it um but those are the two
basic sort of strategies that we've sort of flip-flopped between or tried to combine in various ways um for the last sort of
20 or 30 years um it is it might be a little bit interesting to look at what does
actually mean integration what are we actually trying to make happen well in our world you know one of the things
you're trying to do is you're trying to create links between artifacts and different tools so i've got a test case and that test
case validates that a particular requirement on a particular piece of software is satisfied so i'm trying to make a link
between the test case and the requirement that it satisfies or something like that um
often within one tool i need to be able to create an artifact in another you know the build runs
and a bad thing happens and i get some kind of debug information out of the out of the build right i was running a
test case the build failed i'd like to open a defect right so the build engine there isn't a human being who can sit
there and type it out and the build engine wants to automatically create a defect and that defect has to be in a defect management tool and sometimes i
just want to select so this was really there was an existing requirement i wanted to select it and join it to the test case in this case there was no
existing defect i wanted to create one and tie it into some kind of test failure record or something like that
i'd also like to share common concepts that's so um one of the things one of the integration
things that you want to have happen is that it's not just that the tools are separate and you want to integrate them you actually want to combine things so
we all you know i've got testers requirements people doing defects people doing source code we all kind of know
that we're working on the same product and that product has certain releases so there are certain of these kind of
central pieces of data that you'd really like to share and we've never been good at that
you know what actually happens is right right from the beginning install the tool and then you define a set of users in this tool and a set of users in that
tool and a set of users in the next tool and you create a project in this tool and a project in that tool and project so there's a whole bunch of sort of
shared stuff that we're not good at um you want to be able to query which was one of the reasons why people were so
drawn to this kind of central repository kind of thing so um my sort of sample query from our domain again not hard to
imagine in different domains my sample query from our debate is give me a list of all the new test cases that i should
run on last night's build so i thought that shouldn't be very complicated right
i know what the build was i know what change sets went into the build i know what defects are requirements that those
change sets were related to and i know what the test cases are for those defects or requirements so a good
old-fashioned sort of relational join across four tables ought to be able to get me the answer
show me all the tests show me all the new test cases to run on last night's build but in fact has been relatively
difficult to do in practice in this kind of heterogeneous kind of environment so that's some of the things that we want to get out of
this so having spent a long time and a lot of
money getting as far as we could with those two old ways of doing integration and
lots of variants lots of variants that we thought were new but which were when you really looked at the essentials

in object orientation we're used to the fact that everything's an instance of one and only one type in rdf an instance

right so if you're a member of this class then you must have a hair color and a name and a title and things like that
rds is all about working the other way rdf says if you have this characteristic
then you must be a member of this type not if you're a member of this type then you must have this characteristic
